distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.title: John Herring v. J.C. Jewett.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: John Herring vs J.C. Jewett Sheriff Whatcom County
Before Judge Fitzhugh Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and District Judge of the 3rd Judicial District Washington Territory

John Herring plaintiff in the above writ 1st he cause complains of J.C. Jewett defendant herein, and for cause of complaint sets forth, that the said plaintiff is restrained of his liberty by the said J.C. Jewett, acting as Sheriff of the County of Whatcom in said Territory that said restraint is imposed in the Town of What- com in the same, under the order of the Judges of the Probate Criminal Court of said County to wit N. Young presiding Judge and H.R Crosbie Associate

2nd The cause or pretense of the restraint has been, that one Moses Phillips made a com- plaint against said plaintiff on oath in the said Criminal Court as for a public nuisance, and complained that said plaintiff kept a number of hogs, roaming about the streets, and lying under houses breeding filth and that he had built a pig jam in the streets

To this complaint the defendant therein by his counsel demand, on the ground, that hogs lying under teh houses of some citizens, and breed- ing filth be it true, was a private nuisance, and not a public one. Also that the allegation that the hogs roamed about the streets did not contain facts sufficnet to constitute a criminal acion; which was overuled by the Court.

Defendant then filed his answer stating that the hogs in question did not belong to him, that the pig jam was not an obstruction to the street nor was any person prevented from passing along the same - that said pass way was not a public street so for as he knew, and that it was only used by foot people, and not by waggons - and that he was not guilty of a public offense - on the trial defendant's counsel asked six instructions, onyl of of which was given. See paper on file.
The trial was had on the 27th day of April 1859 and the Jury brought in a verdict of guilty fine $5 Costs $115 Total $120
(When the verdict was rendered) When the ver- dict was rendered the Court ordered the said veridct to be recorded as a judgment and immediately adjourned the Court.

On the convening the Court next morning the 28th the defendant's Counsel moved the Court for a new trial on three grounds: First Newly discovered evidence. Second Misdirection of the Jury and admission of illegal evidence, and Third, Refusal of the Court to allow defendant to be heard by Counsel before the Jury. By all which said then defendant Herring was materially in regard to his substantial rights.
This application was refused on the grounds that it should have been made before judgment; which if it be a judgment would be impossible as no time intervened to permit it
These are the causes according to the best of the knowledge of complainant

The restraint is alleged to be illegal on the grounds, just, that the verdict was recorded as a judgment and not as a verdict - therefore the verdict was not recorded as such. Second, that no sentence was legally imposed nor judg- ment entered. Third, that defendant was not called nor did he appear for sentence nor was he asked. "Whether he had any legal cause to show why judgment should not be
